fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51307].
  {panel}

When calendar events are displayed on the dashboard, the name of the calendar is included in brackets to the right of the event name.
When a user clicks on an event within the month or week view, the name of the calendar is not displayed, but it is assumed that the user will be able to determine the calendar name from the event colour. When there are a lot of calendars involved in a single view, this becomes difficult. 
In the event view, include the name of the calendar.
On the list view, also include the name of the calendar similar to the way it is displayed on the dashboard.
fields.summary: Display the name of the calendar on the detail pop-up and on the list view
Summary field (in People Calendars) should be made bigger

Creating this on behalf of a customer.

This is best explained by the following screenshot:
!teamcal.jpg!
The problem here is that users might accidentally click on the greyed dates as highlighted in the picture and create an event in the wrong month. We could either limit the ability to create events in a different month, or better differentiate the different months in a single view.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51301].
  {panel}

Ideally meetings rooms could be resources attached or scheduled into a meeting...these would have their own availability calendars and be linked to location or really they would define location (Meeting Room 2, Level 4, 30 Gawler Rd).

Rooms could have specs: number of people it can hold, projector, whiteboard etc

i.e I want to schedule a meeting: I find an available meeting room an invite it to the meeting as well...this could be done with other resources (laptops, projectors, vehicles, etc).

I need a corporate car to get somewhere for a meeting...I can book it it out?

This might rely on seeing availability across multiple calendars.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51296].
  {panel}

When a user creates a calendar, they are given write/view permissions to the calendar which are immutable.  

*Why this is a problem*
There is no mention anywhere of who created a specific calendar.  This means that unless you know exactly who created the calendar there is no way to know for sure who does and does not have access to the calendar.  More importantly, there are no restrictions you can enact that will keep the creator from viewing/editing a calendar they have created.

*Use case*
There are a number of scenarios that I can think of as to why the creator would need to be excluded, these include standard role changes/resignations/replacements etc.  I can also see a person entering a mass of new calendars for a company (Think repetitive data entry following a known format) that is later tweaked by the group it is associated with.  After the creation of the calendar, these groups may want to restrict their calendar but they would have no idea that the creator would still be able to view/edit their calendar.
fields.summary: Change immutable permissions granted to creator of calendar
Ability to select a particular date on calendar from a drop down menu rather than scrolling to it manually

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51292].
  {panel}

As can be seen from the attached screenshot, the jira issue on the right has the value of 30th December 2011 for the fields "JC Issue Due Date" and "JC Lets scynchronise"

Both of these fields have been mapped in the Edit Calendar dialog.

It has been approximately 15 minutes since the issue was created but it is still yet to be reflected on the Jira calendar.

This is definitely not a caching issue as the changes were not seen on a fresh browser that had not displayed the calendar before the changes were made.

I've found that during release planning, there's a lot of friction to create this - I bounce in and out of Team Calendars in to JIRA.

What if I could create my JIRA releases from Team Calendars? 

Concepts: 
!teamcal-create-jira-versions1.png!

!teamcal-createjiraversions-2.png!

We could also extend it to have the concept of a "Start date" for a JIRA version, but that would be a specific field on the Confluence side.

Interested to hear customer feedback / thoughts on this

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51284].
  {panel}

Grouping calendars for larger organisations can be challenging. Why is this important? Users often want to logically group a set of calendars together so that they can:

* Embed a set of calendars related to a specific team on a page (embed via category/label)
* Share a set of calendars for a team ("hey, here are our team calendars")
* Report / search for calendars by category/label.

We've got a similar concept in Confluence Space Categories, we should consider following a _similar_ model.

When you subscribe to an external calendar URL, the "Subscribe" button is smart enough to say "Subscribing" when you paste the URL..

We should make some UX improvements to this:

# It should say "Subscribing..." 
# The button should be disabled when it is attempting to subscribe

If the URL is invalid, the button gets enabled again and it says "Subscribe" (which is fine now).
If the URL is valid it closes the dialog (which is fine now).

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51236].
  {panel}

h3.Currently on Team Calendars, each time you try to import an .ics file it will create a new calendar on the fly.

The expected behavior would be to add/merge with the current created calendar.

h3.Workaround
# Have a Google Account.
# Log into your Calendar, Settings
# And then select "Import Calendar"
# Then start merging all calendars you'd like to add.
# When finished Export this ics
# Import in Team Calendars
fields.summary: Allow ability to merge .ics files into a single Calendar

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51235].
  {panel}

Original Request:
I want to be able to set a keyword filter, to display only certain events of a Team Calendar on a Confluence page. But it is not feasible to create multiple Calendars because it will be a maintenance nightmare.
Perhaps when you add the gadget, one of the fields can let you filter by keyword.

Related:
Another option would be to consider introducing "Event" types and allowing users to make their own events and filter by the event types. This overlaps with TEAMCAL-523 quite a bit.

fields.summary: Support Microsoft Exchange Timezone format.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51227].
  {panel}

I think your implementation of "people" calendars could be improved if:
- consider people as resources with availability. (similar to cars, meeting rooms, laptops...except that those resources blindly accept requests, where people to varying degrees (dependent on how empowered they are in their workplace) manage their own commitments and availability.
- each user has their own personal calendar.
- calendar items sync across multiple calendar views (events, team, personal...)
- a team calendar is not about adding things to the current people calendar...but about a user sharing their personal calendar (controls needed about sharing details of events in personal calendar - i.e. I'll share I have a meeting..but not share a sensitive medical appointment...but availability should still be blocked out.) Users are added to the team calendar and availability/calendar items flow across.
-events (such as a meeting) allow aggregation of multiple users into one item on a team calendar

Initial key here is that every user gets a personal calendar...adn the people calendars become about adding people...not people adding personal events...they add those in their personal calendar and may choose to sync with iCAL or Exchange.
fields.summary: People are resources: every users should have a personal calendar - team calendars should be about an aggregated view of personal calendars
Replace link to "Close" with button like "OK" and "Delete"

This is very similar to the Confluence "Manage watchers" feature

Currently, all the upcoming events within 5 days are displayed on Confluence dashboard.
The customer is adding many events in My Calendars and cannot see the dashboard well.

So we want a filter feature for limiting the number of upcoming events displayed by user's specified clauses (e.g. date range of created events).

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51202].
  {panel}

When you embed a calendar in week view, each (non full day) event is preceded with it's time. This is a problem in two ways: 
# it is redundant with week view mode because week view already displays items by time. 
# it causes some useful content to spill outside the visible area of an event.   

-This is easily observed, but let me know if you'd like a screenshot.- screenshot added.
fields.summary: Event time is redundant in week view, should hide it.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51201].
  {panel}

We've recently installed TeamCal 1.9.1, and noticed that when adding a new Jira calendar from our primary Jira instance, the UI can appear to be frozen.
After a certain period of time the UI becomes usable, and date and time fields appear from Jira in a list.

When using Chrome developer tools to see what was happening during the quiet period, it became clear that TeamCal was retrieving the Jira information.
This appeared to be in the form of a file called options.JSON

For larger Confluence/Jira instances like ours, it's important that if an operation takes longer than say 1/2 secs, there should be an indication that something is happening.
In this case, some form of dialog or spinner should be added to the "New Jira Calendar" dialog box until everything has loaded and the user can actually use the form.

Furthermore, when switching between the "Project" and "Saved Filter" radio button, there can be a few seconds lag. I think this is more of a client side rendering issue, but again it's possible for the user to see a spinner while the browser is doing it's thing, and disappearing when the dialog box is ready for use again.
fields.summary: Improve visual feedback when New Jira  Calendar dialog is communicating with Jira in the background

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51198].
  {panel}

See attached...


We have a monthly calendar with alot of staff vacations per day/week, it's hard to see the current day and the table borders are so light it's hard to see which day the event is on, people get confused on what week they are looking at.

Possible solutions
1. make the table border a little darker
2. Better highlight the current day
3. Reduce the banners to make the days easier to see, etc

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51197].
  {panel}

As a product manager looking to roll out team calendars for our organisation for managing our client event schedule, I need to be able to add some custom parameters to Event Calendars so our users can accurately create events.

The options of a lick list or an external database connection would be ideal.

Specifically we need:
Client - look up our client DB
Category - pick list
Office - pick list

If this isn't part of your roadmap, would building this functionality into our instance void our support agreement?

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51191].
  {panel}

Here is the reproduction procedure: 
# Create a new calendar called "test" with the admin user account. 
# Log in with another user account called "localuser" and add the calender "test" in his watch list.
# Log in with the admin user account again, then change the calendar name from "test" to "changename".
# Log in with user account "localuser" again, then display the calendar, we can see that the calendar name is still "test" instead of "changename", but the data is still the same.

It looks like a name display issue.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51190].
  {panel}

Now that we have the calendar key in the macro, we've still got a few holes we need to fill.

* There is no way to toggle the calendar on/off form the view
* There is no way to apply restrictions to the calendar from the viewpage 
* There is no way to subscribe/watch a calendar form the viewpage as well
... 
List goes on... we probably don't need all functionality available, but we can talk about that later (requires quick spec). 

This incorporates:
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/TEAMCAL-112
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/TEAMCAL-181
* ... probably some others

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-51172].
  {panel}

This issue is to track the general ability to create team rosters. This would include the following stories:

* As a roster owner, I can define a team/list of people that are in the roster
* Team Calendars can automatically generate a roster for me based on some rules
(e.g Duration of roster period, frequency) 
* Nice-to-have Ability to define roster roles (primary support contact, stand-buy contact) etc... for each person.


... there is a lot we could do here, if you are interested in this feature please comment below and share what specific part of this feature is the biggest pain point for you? If we could solve one of these problems what would it be? What is the most painful part about organising a roster?
Cheers, 
Team Calendars team

Customer Feedback from Pieter:
{code}
Good day,

I would like to use the Team Calendars to automate our standby process. 
The current process involves a Excel spreadsheet macro where the macro automatically fills in the next team member on standby (it iterates through a list of available members). It also flags the standby as a problem if there is a conflicting task such as leave.

Note:
- There can be different sets of groups consisting of the same people
- You can specify which group of people is active from which period onwards
- The calendar can have different sets of standby's (qa, live, south africa, namibia etc) which can use a group of people.

Please do ask me if you have any questions. I've attached an example which might assist.

Thanks!
  Pieter
{code}

Several other calendars products parse object field on event creation in order to determine times, dates and other useful data.
Adding JQL like capabilities to TeamCalendars for this would be great

References : Fantastical http://flexibits.com/fantastical
Backpack : http://backpackit.com (need to have paid plan)
